Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/30/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not
result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS:
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CPA Rule 400-12605 (1) Adoptive Family Evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the
family signing an adoption application and prior
to approving a family for adoption.
One of three adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not have comple the written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days. The application was submitted on 3/31/2022 and
the evaluation was written on 6/15/2023.
FOM 722 -06B Family Team Meeting: Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames.
Post FTM
Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, to all participants (in person and by phone),
legal parents, and casework supervisor. These
documents must also be uploaded into MISACWIS.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
2

Two of six foster care case records reviewed lack the required DHHS 1105 Activity
report uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL, DATED 6/29/22, CAP DATED
7/18/22
FOM 722 – 08D Treatment plans: Agreements and Signatures
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisors, when sibling in care
are placed apart.
• Parents who are a member of participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parent, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court - ordered caregivers.
Five of six, (fourteen PATP’s) open foster care case records showed signatures that
were late, unsigned and/or no check in the boxes indicating participation from the
caregivers.
FOM 801 – 03 Medical Passport: Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical
passport must be current and updated at least
quarterly to reflect the child’s current and
complete health information.
Three of six open case records reviewed lack quarterly updated of the youth medical
passport. One child did not have a medical passport in the case record.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAPs) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency submitted two approved acceptable corrective action plans during this
reporting period.
Special Investigation #2022C0001018 was generated on 5/20/22, CAP was
accepted on 8/12/22. The agency was in violation with R400.12713 (5) Adoption
placement records. The agency has followed their CAP with this violation.
Renewal Inspection was completed on 6/29/2023, CAP was approved on 7/13/22.
The agency was in violation with rules 400.12212 (2) Personnel records,
400.12326 (1, g) Borrowed home, 400.12418 (2) Development of service plans,
FOM 722-6B Family Team meeting, FOM 722-08C Required Participation in
Development -Foster parent/caregiver. The agency has one repeat violation
during this reporting period.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators discussed at the exit conference barriers that have
impacted compliance. She reported the agency continues to have staffing and
parents not being consistent with their contact or compliance. She reported
although the agency is addressing social work contacts on a consistent basis this
area continues to need improvement. She said the social work contacts for
parents/children and parents/workers are the most concerning. The agency had a
lot of parents that are inconsistent with attending parenting time and complying
with their PATP’s. This has impacted the agency ability to improve in the KPI
areas. The workers continue to encourage compliance with the parents. The
agency has also implemented transportation like Uber/Lyft to help support their
foster parents in making it to parenting time visits. The agency continues to have
COVID related barriers although, not as prevalent as before. She said face-to-face
contacts are not always feasible due to exposures or clients/staff having COVID.
Financial Overview
The agency provided their annual audit by an independent certified public
accountant an annual budget for the current fiscal year. No concerns were noted.
4

Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff interviewed love the cultural values of the agency and provided with
curiosity and the benefit of doubt opposed to making a person feel guilty. The
agency motto is to serve each other with respect. Staff feel very supported by
their coworkers, supervisors and the administration. The one wish expressed was
for a reduction in the amount of paperwork, and the ability to have more time with
families helping them meet their goals.
There were no youth interviews.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no areas of safety concerns when toured the staff offices and other
areas in the facility.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
The agency had four safety alerts this reporting period.
Alert #1.
Concern:
The bedroom that's designated for the foster child has a sliding door and there is no
alarm on the door. There is a lake located directly behind the home.
Two beds are located in the basement and there isn’t a means of egress. Also,
improper storage of medication was observed in the home.
An alarm is needed for the sliding bedroom door. A signed safety plan is needed to
address the beds in the basement. A locked box for medication is needed to ensure
the medication is securely stored and out of reach. Photos are attached to this alert.
Resolution:
Licensing Supervisor spoke with caregiver, on 6/30/203 and she indicated she was
aware of the safety concerns. Caregiver has an alarm on the sliding door in the
youth bedroom; but it was not turned on when the home visit occurred. Caregiver
agrees to keep the alarm always turned on when youth is in her home.
Caregiver indicated she does not have any prescription medication at this time, but
her over-the-counter medications and vitamins are stored out of reach in her
bedroom closet shelf that is too high for youth to reach. Caregiver stated there was
an old pill bottle on her nightstand filled with quarters at the time of the home visit.
Caregiver already has a lock box, and she agrees to keep all medication and pill
bottles in the lock box.
Caregiver indicated no one sleeps in the beds in the basement overnight where the
two extra beds were viewed. She explained that when she is overheated upstairs or
stressed out, she will rest in the basement on one of the beds, but it is only for a
short amount of time. The home has three bedrooms upstairs and there are three
household members. Each household member has their own bedroom upstairs that
5

is appropriately furnished. Caregiver agrees to not allow anyone to sleep in the
basement as there is no egress.
Alert #2.
Concern:
Two entrance/exit doors which leads to the pool and spa doesn't have a compliant
alarm. Alarms are needed for the door located in the sunroom/spa room and the
garage door. Photos are attached to this alert.
Resolution:
Foster Care Worker observed at the home visit on 6/26/23 that the home had alarms
on the doors leading to the backyard and the room containing the spa, including the
two doors pictured in the safety alert. One is the garage door leading from the
garage to the backyard and the other is the door between the room containing the
spa and the back porch.
Alert #3.
Concern:
Safety in the home could not be verified due to the foster parent refusing access.
Foster Parent was contacted on 6/12/23 and she communicated that she will not
participate with the DCWL home visit, and she is submitting paperwork to request
closure of her foster care license.
Resolution:
Attempts were made to contact the provider with no response until 6/21/2023.
Caregiver stated she wanted to close her foster home license as she had provided
permanency to her relatives and had no desire for any other placements. The
license closure was initiated and was officially closed on 6/26/2023. A screenshot
from the provider record showed the home close in CWLM.
Alert #4.
Concern:
The foster parent has a hot tub/spa and there is no alarm on the door which leads to
the hot tub/spa.
Resolution:
The Caregiver deflated the spa and removed it from the backyard. She did not want
to put up an alarm currently. She sent a picture of emptying the spa and of the
backyard after it was removed. Pictures attached.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Oakland Family Services continue on their regular license.
